entry.def: One of the five major poetic genres that Petrarch uses in the Rvf, representing 2.23% of the compositions in Part I (6 of 263), .9% of those in Part II (1 of 103), and 1.91% of the entire Rvf. There are two essential variations that we find among the 366 poems: the ballata mezzana and the ballata grande. Both forms are read horizontally, across the charta in Petrarch’s transcription strategy. The mezzana (middle) form begins with a refrain of three verses. The grande (long) form begins with a refrain of four verses. In the last form of Vat Lat. 3195 before Petrarch’s death there are three ballate mezzane: Rvf 55, c. 13r (Quel foco), Rvf 59, c. 13v (Perché quel che mi trasse), and Rvf 324, c. 63r (Amor, quando fioria). A fourth ballata mezzana, Donna mi vene spesso ne la mente, resided in the position of Rvf 121 before Petrarch’s late substitution (after 1368) of the madrigal Or vedi, Amor (c. 26r). Rvf 55 and 59 present 17vv-models copied by the principal copyist on ten lines. Each contains a refrain plus two stanzas divided prosodically into four verses of a mutazione and three verses of a volta, which concludes by returning to the concluding rhyme of refrain (ripresa): Rvf 55 = XYY ABAB BYY / CDCD DYY; Rvf 59: XyY AbAb ByY CdCdDyY. Both demonstrate significant metrical variations between hendecasyllables and settenari, using —however — the same rhyme scheme. The monostanzaic Rvf 324 = xYY AbCB aCcYY, transcribed on seven lines, shows an additional set of variations, while the rejected Donna mi vene (former 121), copied on six lines, yet another: XyX ABA BCCY. The four ballate grandi all appear in Part I: Rvf 11, c. 2r (Lassare il velo), Rvf 14, c. 2v (Occhi miei), Rvf 63, c. 14r (Volgendo gli occhi), and Rvf 149, c. 33r (Di tempo in tempo). Rvf 11, 14, and 63 are all 14-v ballate transcribed on seven lines. Rvf 11 and 14 demonstrate minor prosodic variations: Rvf 11 = XyYX ABCBACC dDX; Rvf 14 = XYyX ABCB ACC DdX. Rvf 63 is entirely in hendecasyllables = XYYX ABCB ACC DDX. Transcribed on eight lines, the 16-v ballata Rvf 149 includes additional variations: mid-verse rhyme in v. 2 and the doubling of the settenario b-rhyme in the mutazioni: X(x)YyX AbbCAbbC CDdX. (see and “Genere-ballata” in Storey, “All’interno della poetica grafico-visiva di Petrarca”, pp. 157–59)
A gathering, or quire, of two sheets folded to produce four chartae, eight sides.

A collection of folded sheets of parchment, or bifolia, each placed inside another to make a material unit of between four (binion) and ten (quinion) or more chartae. Petrarch’s partial holograph, Vaticano Latino 3195, contains only binions and quaternions (4 and 8 chartae respectively).
A gathering, or quire, of four sheets folded to produce eight chartae, sixteen sides.
